summary: This document appears to be notes from an evening call on December 3, 2021, with Gail Goodman, discussing the government's expert notice regarding Elizabeth Loftus and the psychology of child sexual abuse and trafficking victims. It covers memory accuracy, common victim behaviors, and research methods.

persons.name: Gail Goodman
persons.context: Participated in an evening call to discuss the government's expert notice regarding Elizabeth Loftus and the psychology of child sexual abuse victims.

persons.name: Elizabeth Loftus
persons.context: Her expert notice was sent by the government to Gail Goodman; her research methods on memory are discussed in the context of child sexual abuse cases.

connections.description: Goodman received and reviewed the government's expert notice regarding Loftus and discussed Loftus's research methods.

events.title: Evening call with Gail Goodman
events.description: A call was held to discuss the government's expert notice on Elizabeth Loftus and topics related to child sexual abuse victim psychology.

keyFacts: The government sent Gail Goodman an expert notice regarding Elizabeth Loftus and a revised draft document.
The discussion noted that initial denial of child sexual abuse is not uncommon for victims who have been trafficked, distrust authorities, or were told not to tell.
Victims in this context are usually teenagers, with other results common for children aged 7 to under 18.
The notes indicate that when people converse with others, it can help memory be more accurate.
Other researchers use methods similar to those of Elizabeth Loftus.
